<final_answer>
Below are two safe, complete options you can run locally (or run here if the environment later allows GitHub API calls). Both require a GitHub personal access token (PAT) with repo scope and network access.

A. Bash script using curl + GitHub REST API
- What it does:
  1) Fetches collaborator usernames for emmajohnson/image_transformation
  2) Creates a repository named new_project under the authenticated account
  3) Invites each collaborator to the new repository (permission = push)

Save this as create_and_invite.sh, make executable (chmod +x), set GITHUB_TOKEN in your environment, and run.

#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail

# Configuration
SRC_OWNER="emmajohnson"
SRC_REPO="image_transformation"
NEW_REPO="new_project"
TOKEN="${GITHUB_TOKEN:-}"

if [ -z "$TOKEN" ]; then
  echo "Error: Please set GITHUB_TOKEN environment variable with a PAT that has repo scope."
  exit 1
fi

API="https://api.github.com"

# Determine authenticated username (owner for new repo)
AUTH_USER=$(curl -s -H "Authorization: token $TOKEN" "$API/user" | jq -r '.login // empty')
if [ -z "$AUTH_USER" ]; then
  echo "Error: Could not determine authenticated user. Check GITHUB_TOKEN."
  exit 1
fi
echo "Authenticated as: $AUTH_USER"

# 1) Get collaborators of the source repo (usernames)
echo "Fetching collaborators for $SRC_OWNER/$SRC_REPO ..."
collabs=$(curl -s -H "Authorization: token $TOKEN" "$API/repos/$SRC_OWNER/$SRC_REPO/collaborators?per_page=100" | jq -r '.[].login' )

if [ -z "$collabs" ]; then
  echo "Warning: No collaborators found or access denied to $SRC_OWNER/$SRC_REPO."
fi

# 2) Create the new repo under authenticated user
echo "Creating repository $AUTH_USER/$NEW_REPO ..."
create_resp=$(curl -s -o /dev/stderr -w "%{http_code}" -X POST \
  -H "Authorization: token $TOKEN" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d "{\"name\":\"$NEW_REPO\",\"private\":false}" \
  "$API/user/repos")

if [ "$create_resp" -ge 400 ]; then
  echo "Warning: repository creation returned status $create_resp (it may already exist or you may lack permissions)."
fi

# 3) Invite each collaborator to the new repo
echo "Inviting collaborators to $AUTH_USER/$NEW_REPO ..."
for u in $collabs; do
  echo " - Inviting $u ..."
  invite_resp=$(curl -s -o /dev/null -w "%{http_code}" -X PUT \
    -H "Authorization: token $TOKEN" \
    -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    -d '{"permission":"push"}' \
    "$API/repos/$AUTH_USER/$NEW_REPO/collaborators/$u")
  if [ "$invite_resp" -ge 400 ]; then
    echo "   -> Invite for $u returned HTTP $invite_resp"
  else
    echo "   -> Invite sent (HTTP $invite_resp)"
  fi
done

echo "Done."

Notes about the script:
- If the source repo is private, your PAT must have read access to that repo. If it’s on another account and private, you might not be able to list collaborators unless you are the repo owner or have appropriate access.
- Invite API uses GitHub usernames. Public email addresses are not necessary. If you need to invite by email instead, you can modify the logic, but the API endpoint for inviting by email is different and may not be available for all account types.
- The new repo is created as public in the script (private: false). Change to private: true if you want it private.

B. Using GitHub CLI (gh) — shorter and convenient
Prereqs: gh installed and authenticated (gh auth login), jq installed.

# Create repo
gh repo create new_project --public --confirm

# Get collaborator usernames from the source repo
collabs=$(gh api repos/emmajohnson/image_transformation/collaborators --jq '.[].login')

# Invite each collaborator to the new repo (new repo assumed created under your authenticated user)
OWNER=$(gh api user --jq .login)
for u in $collabs; do
  echo "Inviting $u ..."
  gh api --method PUT repos/$OWNER/new_project/collaborators/$u -f permission=push
done

Caveats & troubleshooting
- If you get 404 or an empty collaborator list when querying the source repo, likely the repo is private and the token/gh user does not have permission to view collaborators. In that case either:
  - Run the script with a token belonging to an account that owns or has access to emmajohnson/image_transformation; or
  - Ask the owner (emmajohnson) to run these steps themselves or to provide the collaborator list.
- If repository creation fails because new_project already exists in the account, either choose a different name or delete the existing repo first (be careful).

- Run these steps for you here if you enable the environment to allow the GitHub repo actions (get_github_repository_information, git_create_repo, git_invite_collaborators) or
- Proceed if you paste the collaborator usernames/emails for emmajohnson/image_transformation here.

Which would you prefer?
